Graphical abstract Metallic core–shell nanoparticles can be rationally designed for highly efficient electrochemical conversions, due to their unique intrinsic strain, ligand, geometric, and ensemble effects. Metallic core–shell nanoparticles (MCSNs) have attracted significant research interest in electrochemical energy conversion owing to their distinctive microstructures and superior catalytic performances. By rationally designing a metallic core with a specific surface (shell), synergistic interactions between the core and the shell, benefiting from the intrinsic strain, ligand, geometric, and ensemble effects, can endow multi-metallic CSNs with highly enhanced activity, selectivity, and stability in electrocatalytic reactions, compared to their monometallic counterparts. In this review, we outline the key breakthroughs—especially in the past 5 years—of MCSNs, focusing on their precise design/synthesis, intrinsic effects arising from core–shell interactions, state-of-the-art characterization techniques, and exceptional performance in critical electrochemical reactions, including water splitting, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), N2/NO3 − reduction reaction (N2RR/NO3RR), and small organic molecule electrooxidations. We further discuss the ongoing challenges and opportunities for MCSNs, particularly in achieving computationally guided design/atomic-precision synthesis, enabling scalable production, and advancing in situ or operando characterization methods. We hope that the present review will inspire chemists working in this field to develop new MCSNs for sustainable energy applications. Keywords Core-shell structure Metal nanoparticle Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction Accelerated development of electrochemical energy conversion in recent years has been driven by the urgent need to transition from fossil fuels to sustainable energy systems [1]. Electrocatalysis lies at the core of this transition, offering indispensable processes for decarbonizing energy systems [2,3], such as green hydrogen production via water splitting (replacing fossil-derived H2), carbon–neutral fuel synthesis through CO2 electroreduction (CO2RR), sustainable ammonia production via electrochemical N2/NO3 − reduction (N2RR/NO3RR), and clean power generation in fuel cells (e.g., oxygen reduction reaction, ORR). However, the lack of low-cost, efficient, and durable electrocatalysts remains a major challenge for scaling these technologies [4,5]. To address this challenge, various nanomaterials with diverse functions have been developed, including single-metal-atoms [6,7], metal nanoparticles [8,9], metal nitrides [10,11], high-entropy alloys [12,13], metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [14], and porous organic cages [15]. Among these materials, metallic core–shell nanoparticles (MCSNs) have emerged as compelling candidates due to their unique advantages, including substantial cost savings achieved by covering small non-noble metal cores with ultrathin noble metal shells, reducing reliance on scarce Pt-group metals; high accessibility of surface atoms resulting from small grain sizes and abundant crystal planes/defects due to variable compositions and geometric configurations; and efficient reactant activation and product desorption facilitated by strain effects and modified electronic structures caused by lattice mismatch between the core and shell [16–18]. Despite these advantages, synthesizing MCSNs remains challenging, as different metals are prone to phase separation or alloying with self-aggregation, driven by intrinsic miscibility and high surface energy. This complexity underscores the necessity for precise synthesis of MCSNs to make a trade-off among the activity, selectivity and stability to realize their full potential. Recent years have seen significant progresses in wrapping metal cores with ultrathin shells for advanced electrocatalytic applications [19–21]. The rapid developments in characterization techniques have clarified the dynamic growth processes and catalytic mechanisms of MCSNs. Although numerous reviews have covered electrocatalytic nanomaterials [22–27], few have focused on MCSNs for electrocatalysis, particularly lacking a systematic analysis of recent breakthroughs or an integrated discussion linking synthesis-driven effects to performance in emerging reactions. This review aims to summarize recent research progress—especially over the past 5 years—on MCSNs from the standpoint of their synthesis strategies, unique effects, state-of-the-art characterization techniques, and exceptional performance in emerging energy applications, including water splitting, ORR, CO2RR, N2RR/NO3RR, and small organic molecule electrooxidations. We highlight representative MCSNs to correlate their structural effects (strain, ligand, geometry) with mechanistic insights from advanced characterizations, and the role in enhancing catalytic activity beyond monometallic counterparts. In addition, we discuss the ongoing challenges and opportunities for MCSNs—particularly in focusing on achieving atomic-precision synthesis, enabling scalable production, and advancing in situ or operando characterization methods. We hope this review will benefit researchers working in this field, allowing for the rational design of new MCSNs for sustainable energy applications. 2 Synthesis of MCSNs Due to the efficient utilization of surface atoms and cost-effective materials, core–shell structures have garnered significant attention in electrocatalytic applications. Here, we focus on the synthetic strategies and parameters of MCSNs. Table 1 summarizes the key aspects of MCSNs, including advantages of synthesis methods, limitations of MCSNs, and benefits and challenges for electrocatalysis. 2.1 Conventional methods The classical method for synthesizing MCSNs involves fabricating metal nanoparticle cores with designed composition, surface, and size, followed by loading targeted materials as layers on the core surfaces through chemical approaches, such as reduction deposition, dealloying, galvanic replacement, cation exchange, Kirkendall effect, and Ostwald ripening [28–36]. Reduction deposition enables atomic-level control over shell formation by precisely regulating reductant concentration, time, and temperature. For instance, Pt3 cluster-decorating Co@Pd CSNs were immobilized on carbon nanotubes by controlled reduction sequences [37]. However, the efficacy of reduction deposition hinges on lattice compatibility and reductant equilibrium. This necessitates a careful balance between interfacial adhesion and reaction kinetics to prevent homogeneous nucleation and shell detachment. The critical aspect of dealloying lies in precise regulation of corrosion depth to prevent core collapse, and controlled surface diffusion kinetics for uniform shell formation. Although dealloying offers simplicity and scalability for industrial manufacturing, it requires precise optimization of alloy composition and corrosion parameters, including acid concentration and temperature, to maintain structural integrity and prevent excessive dissolution. For example, uniform PtNi@Pt CSNs with a 0.8 nm-thick shell were formed on graphene via controllable galvanic replacement combined with partial dealloying, resulting in a gradient distribution of composition from surface to interior [38]. This process leveraged the difference in acid resistance between Pt and Ni to selectively remove Ni and reconstruct the Pt shell. Similarly, leaching surface Fe from AuFe nanoparticles in electrolysis, AuFe@Au CSNs with rich surface defects were formed (Fig. 1 ) [39]. The galvanic replacement technique enables fast reaction rates, completing within seconds under mild conditions. This method facilitates the creation of unique architectures, including defect, hollow, or porous structures, through precise control of ion concentration and reaction duration. For example, galvanic replacement of Cu nanoparticles derived from the pyrolysis of Cu-MOFs resulted in the formation of Cu@Pt CSNs anchored on porous carbon [40]. Similarly, galvanic replacement reaction of Pd, Pt, and Au cations with Ag0 yielded bimetallic Ag@AgM or Ag@M (M = Pd, Pt, Au) CSNs [41]. The spontaneous formation of core–shell nanostructures via redox reactions between metallic Ag cores and high-valent metal ions (Mn+) in solution enabled reductant-free deposition of shell materials (Pd, Au and Pt). However, this method is limited to metals with low reduction potentials and high-valent ions, where the mismatch in redox potential poses inherent challenges in precisely controlling shell thickness. The Kirkendall effect leverages differential diffusion rates between metal atoms to fabricate hollow or core–shell structures. When the diffusion rate disparities are insufficient, this phenomenon may not occur, and prolonged reactions may completely deplete the core material, resulting in hollow structures without a residual core. For example, driven by the Kirkendall effect, well-defined Cu@CuAu CSNs were formed by galvanic replacement between pre-synthesized Cu nanocubes and Au3+ ions [42]. In contrast, Ostwald ripening, driven by surface energy differences, enables the uniform synthesis of core–shell structures through dissolution of smaller particles and preferential growth of larger ones. This mechanism is particularly advantages for applications requiring high-density shells, but remains constrained by slow reaction kinetics and restricted shell thickness control. To overcome these limitations, optimization strategies such as photo/thermal stimulation or ligand engineering are necessary. For example, PtCo nanoparticles were transformed into PtCo@Pt CSNs via Ostwald ripening during hydrogen annealing [43]. Such synthesis entailed two distinct stages: (a) annealing disordered Pt3Co at 150 °C in H2, which induced phase ordering and segregation of a Pt-rich bilayer, effectively inhibiting Co oxidation; (b) subsequent treatment at 700 °C, which drove precise atomic migration of Pt to (100) facets, facilitating layer-by-layer Pt shell growth through Ostwald ripening. Electrodeposition is highly effective for fabricating precise, dense MCSNs, particularly when precise control over shell thickness and composition is required. By applying an external electric field, Ni shells were uniformly deposited on prefabricated Cu nanowires [44]. A dual-channel scanning electrochemical cell microscopy (SECCM) technique enabled the electrodeposition of Cu@Pt and Pt@Cu with precise, independent control over elemental distribution, layer sequence, and shell thickness by dynamically modulating the ionic environment, which allowed simultaneous synthesis and high-throughput screening of HER and ORR activities [45]. Successful implementation depends on the design of the conductive substrate and stringent regulation of deposition kinetics. Optimization strategies such as pulsed electrodeposition, additive engineering, or composite electrolyte systems can effectively address challenges related to uniformity and interfacial compatibility, thereby expanding the applicability of this method. 2.2 Liquid metal methods In addition to the classical methods, liquid metals with low viscosity can be employed due to their lack of crystalline lattice confinement, allowing atoms to move freely between the surface and interior, and facilitating binding to other metals. For instance, using liquid GaZn alloys as cores, highly dispersed Ga@Ni CSNs with variable Ni-shell proportions were synthesized via a galvanic replacement process under ultrasonic conditions [46]. Notably, neglecting thermodynamic and kinetic considerations for different metal species can lead to the formation of isolated nanocrystals on Ga nanoparticles rather than core–shell nanostructures. 2.3 One-pot methods MCSNs can also be synthesized by one-pot approaches. In one example, by using octadecylamine as a solvent, surfactant and reducing agent simultaneously, uniform Au@Co and Ni@Au nanocrystals were formed in a one-pot wet chemical process [47,48]. In another example, surface-uneven PtPbBi@PtBi nanoplates were synthesized by heating a mixture containing platinum acetylacetonate, lead acetylacetonate, bismuth acetate, ascorbic acid, oleylamine, and 1-octadecene [49]. 2.4 Regulation of synthesis parameters To precisely control the core–shell structures, the role of metal element properties, such as lattice mismatch, binding form, and redox potential, have been extensively investigated. For example, Pd@Pt and Pd@PtCu nanocrystals were achieved by the reduction deposition of Pt and PtCu onto prefabricated Pd seeds [50]. The Pt shells exhibited an epitaxial growth around Pd cores due to the similar lattice between Pt and Pd, while PtCu shells grew preferentially along the (111) crystal facet, forming polyhedral structures through selective adsorption of Cu2+ on Pd surfaces. The microstructures of Au@AgPt CSNs were effectively controlled by regulating the feeding ratios of Ag or Pt precursors under co-reduction conditions involving both galvanic replacement reaction and reduction reaction [51]. Decreasing the Ag precursor ratio led to a thinner Ag layer due to the dominance of the reduction reaction, while decreasing the Pt precursor ratio resulted in fewer Pt granules due to the dominance of the galvanic replacement reaction. The investigation of the deposition of secondary metals on seeds by using scanning probe block copolymer lithography revealed that core–shell structures formed when the hetero-bond strength between seed and deposited atoms exceeds the homo-bond strength between the shell atoms, accompanied by a minor lattice mismatch between the two elements [52]. Precise control over shell composition, thickness and structure can be achieved by regulating reaction parameters, such as temperature, gas pressure, pH, solvent, capping agent, reducing agent, and precursor concentration. For example, a series of halide-free metal acetylacetonate complex precursors with different reactivities were reduced simultaneously across Rh nanocube surfaces under specific conditions such as a controlled dropwise addition rate, reaction temperature and choice of reducing agent, resulting in the formation of Rh@RuRhPdPt CSNs (Fig. 2 ) [53]. In another example, the surface nucleation and diffusion rates of the octahedral CuNi@PtCu nanocrystals were effectively controlled by regulating synthetic conditions, including Pt precursor/capping ligand ratio, reaction temperature and heating rate [54]. In addition, nearly monodisperse Cu@Ru, Cu@Rh, and Cu@Ir CSNs were prepared using a colloidal method [55], where shell thickness and robustness were regulated by metal precursor concentration, particle size was controlled by ligand amount, and size distribution was influenced by heating rate and reaction temperature. 3 Unique features of MCSNs Remarkably, unique effects, including strain, ligand, and geometric effects, can be introduced through the growth of a secondary material on metal seeds, which impart distinct physicochemical properties to MCSNs. The strain effect, including tensile and compressive strain at core/shell interfaces, arise from lattice mismatch between core and shell materials, which can alter the metal d-band center, surface adsorption energy, and surface reactivity through long-range interactions (longer than 1∼2 monolayers but less than six monolayers away from the surface) [56,57]. A lattice strain that modifies atom–atom distances on the surface of a particle or within a localized area may differ from the standard atom–atom distance found in bulk materials [58], and the strain intensity can be defined as: ε = d P - d s / d s , where the term of d P is the atom–atom distance on a particle surface, and d s is the distance in bulk materials (Fig. 3 a). This strain effect can result in either compressive or tensile strain in catalysts composed of different atoms. Tensile strain induces a decrease in the d-orbital overlap, resulting in d-band sharpening and center upshift, while a compressive strain causes the d-band broader and center downshift [59]. For example, Au@AuIr CSNs exhibited (111) shape effect and strain effect, with the compression strain of Ir causing a d-band center downshift (Fig. 3b) [60]. In fact, the formation of strain in shell is a complicated process, primarily influenced by the lattice mismatch between core and shell, shell thickness, and core–shell interface structure. For example, by precisely controlling the shell thickness, unique strain effects were achieved on PdCu@Ir CSNs while eliminating ligand effects, thus optimizing the d-band center and enhancing the electrocatalytic performance for overall water splitting [61]. The presence of large Bi atoms in the shell of FePt@PtBi CSNs introduced a strong compressive strain with shortened Pt–Pt bonds, endowing such CSNs with enhanced catalytic performance and resistance to poisoning for ORR (Fig. 4 ) [62]. The structure of Pd@Pt core–shell nanocrystals can be tailored to icosahedral, octahedral, or cubic forms by regulating the number of atomic layers in the Pt shell [63]. Pd@Pt nanocrystals with a 3-atomic-layer Pt shell and icosahedral structure demonstrated optimal electrocatalytic activity for H2O2 decomposition and glucose oxidation due to the compressive strain in the Pt shell. Furthermore, lattice strain in core–shell structures was enhanced by increasing shell thickness (usually about 3–5 atomic layers) [64–67], but gradually disappeared with further increases in shell thickness due to lattice relaxation. Ligand effects in MCSNs primarily arise from charge transfer between core and shell materials, often resulting in electronegativity or orbital overlap changes due to hybridization [68–71]. Ligand effect is observed when the growth of 1–2 monolayers of materials in the shell is intertwined with the strain effect [72,73]. For instance, Pd3Pb@Pt3Pb nanocubes exhibited exceptional ORR performance with mass activity of 4.69 A mgPt −1 and specific activity of 6.69 mA cm−2 [74]. As confirmed by geometrical phase analysis (GPA) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the prominent ligand effect from d-d orbital interactions between Pd and Pt and strong p-d orbital hybridization between Pt and Pb were responsible for enhanced catalytic performance. A representative case involves Pd3Ru1@Pt core–shell nanoplates synthesized with lattice-matched interfaces, which eliminated strain effects while enabling sole investigation of ligand effects [71]. Studies confirmed electron donation from the PdRu core to the Pt shell, increasing the electron density in Pt 5d orbitals and lowering its d-band center. This ligand-effect-engineered Pd3Ru1@Pt exhibited exceptional ORR activity, achieving mass activity of 10.3 A mgPt −1 (alkaline) and 4.59 A mgPt −1 (acid) at 0.9 V vs. RHE, significantly outperforming commercial Pt/C catalysts (Fig. 5 ). This work provides the first experimental decoupling of ligand effects, demonstrating that electronic modulation alone can optimize intermediate adsorption energetics and thereby enhance ORR performance. Lattice mismatch and other distinct physical and chemical properties between core and shell materials in MCSNs can induce unique geometric configurations on their surfaces [22]. Variations in facets, surface defects, and sizes are crucial factors influencing geometric effects. For example, ultrafine MCSNs tend to expose more unsaturated atoms rather than saturated atoms on their shell surfaces, and their distinct local geometries show different abilities for bond breaking and forming in electrochemical reactions [75,76]. Another example is the use of Pd (111) tetrahedrons as seeds to fabricate Pd@M (M = Pt, Ru, Rh) CSNs, where the architectures were highly dependent on the shell thickness (Fig. 6 ) [77]. Tetrahedral core–shell architectures emerged when the thickness was below 5 atomic layers, due to the surface atom replication predominantly governing the structural growth. In contrast, when exceeding this critical thickness, Pd@Ru demonstrated hcp-phase stacking behavior, Pd@Rh adopted fcc-phase stacking, while Pd@Pt transformed into truncated octahedrons, attributed to the prevailing spontaneous orientation of individual metals during crystallization. Such Pd@Pt and Pd@Ru CSNs showed the component-dependent ORR and facet-dependent HER performances, respectively. A notable case involves Pd@Pt CSNs with lattice-expanded Pt (100) and Pt (111) facets [78]. The Pt (111) facet exhibited superior catalytic performance for methanol oxidation reaction (MOR), attributed to enhanced OH adsorption that facilitated H2O dissociation into Pt-OH species, thereby promoting oxidative removal of surface-bound CO intermediates. Geometric effects, governed by atomic arrangements (e.g., step edges, kinks, facets, defects, particle sizes), can modulate both strain and ligand interactions. The intertwined influence of strain, ligand, and geometric effects can lead to enhanced outcomes through a synergistic effect. Few research efforts aimed to decouple these effects to individual variables, thereby enabling accurate prediction of structure-catalytic performance relationships. For example, PdCu@Ir CSNs with a 4-atomic-thick shell exhibited a compressive strain of 3.6 %, while eliminating the ligand effects due to the thick shell [79]. However, in most cases, it is challenging to distinguish strain, ligand, and geometric effects through experimental approaches, due to their close interactions within an MCSN [80]. 4 Advanced characterization techniques for MCSNS State-of-the-art analytical techniques provide key information on composition, size, interface, morphology, surface electronic structure, and active site of MCSNs, revealing deep insights into their structure–activity relationships and catalytic mechanisms. In this regard, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) is critical to analyse the purity, crystallinity, phase, and structural integrity of MCSNs, while XPS is informative to probe coordination environment and surface electronic structure. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and TEM effectively visualize size, morphology, dispersibility, and homogeneity of MCSNs. By identifying the lattice fringes with different spacings and bright contrast with different atomic numbers, HRTEM and HAADF-STEM can visualize the two-dimensional distribution of metal core inside the shell from a single particle, and the MCSN’s crystallinity, lattice parameter, crystal orientation, and shell thickness. The aberration-corrected STEM can give such information at atomic resolution. In a given region, EDS mapping can visualize the spatial distribution of constituent elements to confirm the presence of a core–shell structure, and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) can provide the composition, chemical nature, and atomic interaction of MCSNs to investigate their structure-catalytic performance relationships. Surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) effectively monitors the surface changes regarding MCSNs consisting of SERS active elements, such as Au, Ag, and Cu, and can be further used to investigate their surface-catalytic performance relationships. Advanced X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) has recently been developed to give information on the local structure, bonding form, strain, and electronic structure of MCSNs. Until now, by applying these characterization techniques, plenty of MCSNs were confirmed and their structure–activity relationships and catalytic mechanisms were elucidated [16,22]. Characterizing multicomponent MCSNs requres a combination of advanced analytical techniques and computational modeling due to the inherent limitations of individual techniques [81–83]. PXRD fails to resolve sub-2 nm ultrathin shells or amorphous phases, often confounding core–shell architectures with alloyed or Janus-type configurations; XPS provides surface electronic states but is constrained by its shallow probing depth (∼5–10 nm), obscuring core–shell interfacial interactions; SEM/TEM enables atomic-scale lattice mapping at single-particle resolution, yet requires laborious ultramicrotomy and risks electron beam damage to ligand-stabilized structures; SERS effectively probes plasmonic surfaces but loses efficacy for non-plasmonic shell or dielectric coatings exceeding 10 nm thickness; and XAS resolves local coordination and lattice strain but struggles to decouple overlapping signals from core–shell elements with adjacent atomic number. Consequently, characterizing multicomponent MCSNs necessitates a close coordination of various advanced analytical techniques with computational modeling by correlating real-time structural dynamics with theoretical simulations. Recent advancements in in situ reactors and in-time resolved detection techniques have enabled the investigation of the dynamic variations in core–shell structure growth and their catalytic reactions, bridging bulk-averaged spectroscopic data with atomic-level mechanistic insights [84–90]. In particular, in situ liquid cell transmission electron microscopy (LCTEM) and in situ XAS have shown tremendous potential. A good example is the real-time observation of structural evolution of Au@Ag CSNs by using in situ LCTEM highlighted the pivotal role of surfactants in precise construction of core–shell structures [91]. The absence of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) led to direct atomic deposition of Ag shells on Au cores, preferentially coating lateral facets of nanorods while leaving their end facets exposed. Upon introducing PVP, the growth mechanism shifted to a nucleus coalescence-dominated mode, where Ag nanocrystals adsorbed and coalesced onto the Au cores, achieving uniform encapsulation. Similarly, during the observation of the formation of Au@Pd CSNs by in situ LCTEM, the reaction temperature was a crucial factor in determining whether the growth of Pd shells was a kinetic or thermodynamic process. By controlling the reaction temperature, the shape of Au nanorods was tuned to AuPd arrow-headed structures, or cuboidal Au@Pd CSNs (Fig. 7 ) [92]. Furthermore, in situ electrochemical LCTEM enabled direct visualization of corrosion dynamics in Pd@Pt CSNs during cyclic voltammetry [88], revealing preferential oxidative etching of Pd atoms from terrace site, followed by reductive redeposition onto the nanoparticle surface; site-specific corrosion of Pt, where (111) terraces degrade faster than edges/corners; and internal-to-external atomic migration of Pd correlated with redox events in the CV profile (Fig. 8 ). By integrating electrochemical LCTEM observations with stability tests, the investigation demonstrated that consecutive corrosion-redoposition cycles drove the formation of PtPd nanoframes. These findings unequivocally establish electrochemical LCTEM as an indispensable tool for resolving atomic-scale electrochemical degradation mechanisms. Furthermore, in situ inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) combined with X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) analyses elucidated synergistic enhancements in both activity and stability of Au@Pt CSNs for ORR [93]. In situ ICP-MS measurements revealed that Au@Pt exhibited 3.6-fold lower Pt dissolution (10.7 pg cm−2 geo) than pure Pt nanoparticles (10.7 pg cm−2 geo), directly correlating Au presence with suppressed Pt corrosion. In situ XANES demonstrated minimal variation in Pt oxidation states (evidenced by white-line intensity and ΔU values) for Au@Pt within 0.65−1.05 V (vs. RHE), indicating that subsurface ligand effects from the Au core reduce Pt’s oxophilicity. Understanding the strain effect is crucial for elucidating the catalytic properties of MCSNs. However, tracking this complex phenomenon poses significant challenges. Recently, high-precision strain analysis for Cu@Pd CSNs with sharp-core and round-core was characterized by using atomic-resolution annular darkfield scanning transmission electron microscopy (ADF-STEM), affording a <0.18 % strain precision and comprehensive mapping of entire particles over dimensions spanning from a few to hundreds of nanometers (Fig. 9 ) [94]. 5 Promising electrocatalytic applications MCSNs have been extensively investigated as electrocatalysts for energy conversion owing to their low cost, distinct structural tunability, and unique properties. This review highlights their utilization in water splitting, including HER and OER, and other important electrochemical conversions such as ORR, CO2RR, N2RR/NO3RR, and small organic molecule electrooxidations. Table 2 summarizes the synthetic techniques of various MCSNs and their electrocatalytic performances. 5.1 Water splitting Electrochemical water splitting is an ideal way to produce hydrogen, requiring efficient and cost-effective catalysts to facilitate HER at the cathode and OER at the anode [95–102]. Cu@Ni@Ir CSNs showed outstanding activity with low overpotentials of 41 and 262 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for both HER and OER in acidic media and a low cell voltage of 1.53 V for overall water splitting with negligible activity loss over 20 h [103]. The synergistic effects of Cu, Ni, and Ir atoms within the dual core–shell architecture, combined with the high surface area induced by the hierarchical nanoframe structure, contributed to the outstanding electrochemical performance. Since the abundant unsaturated Au atoms around the shell improved the hydrogen adsorption capacity, NiAu@Au CSNs exhibited HER performance in acidic conditions with Pt-like activity and robust durability [104]. Ni@Pd CSNs on polyethyleneimine-reduced graphene (PEI-rGO) exhibited outstanding HER activity in 0.5 M H2SO4 comparable with that of Pt because of the enhancement of electron donation of Pd caused by electron flow from Ni to Pd [105]. In alkaline conditions, fully Pt-covered Ru@Pt CSNs demonstrated higher HER activity than their partially Pt-covered counterparts [106]. This enhanced performance arises because the adjacent Ru core modulates the electronic structure of the surface Pt, thereby lowering hydrogen adsorption barriers and accelerating reaction kinetics. Ni@Ru CSNs on carbon nanosheets exhibited low overpotentials of 20.1 and 356 mV for HER and OER at 10 mA cm−2 and a low potential of 1.6 V for overall water splitting in 1.0 M NaOH [107]. In the Ni@Ru core–shell structure, the ultrathin Ru shell exposed abundant active sites, enhancing electrocatalytic activity and facilitating Ni-to-Ru electron transfer to reduce the adsorption energies of intermediates and accelerate reaction kinetics. Ni@Pt CSNs on N-doped porous carbon showed excellent HER activity in both acidic and alkaline media, which originated from an enlarged electrochemically active surface area and synergistic effects between Ni-core and Pt-shell [108]. Due to the compressive strain-induced downshift of the d-band center for Pd, CuPd@Pd CSNs with a 0.5 nm-thick shell showed Pt-like activities for both HER and ORR in acid electrolytes [109]. Au@Rh mesoporous nanospheres exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity and stability for the HER in all pH solutions, providing low overpotentials of 30, 29 and 24 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4, 1.0 M KOH, and 1.0 M Phosphate Buffered Saline electrolytes, respectively [110]. Due to the lattice tension and modified surface electronic structures, trimetallic PdRu@Pt nanocubes with an average size of 13 nm delivered low overpotentials of 18 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and 489 mV at 500 mA cm−2 for HER in acidic media, while maintaining a remarkable long-term stability for over 24 h [111]. By combining the merits of exposed Pt atoms at facet-edges with the synergistic interactions between strain and ligand effects, electron transfer between Pt active sites and adsorbed hydrogen was significantly enhanced. Anodic OER has slow kinetics and high overpotentials owing to its complex four-electron transfer process and multiple proton-coupling. In this regard, Pd@Ir core–shell nanocubes with controllable Ir shell thickness (atomic layer: 1–4) exhibited a volcano-type trend in their OER activities, and the sample with shell thickness consisting of 3 atomic layers obtained the optimal catalytic performance (an overpotential of 245 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a mass activity of 3.33 A mgIr −1 at 300 mV) [112]. High-entropy alloy shells are found to be more promising. The sub-2 nm IrRuCoNiMo@IrRuNiMoO x CSNs showed excellent OER activity and stability in acidic media [113]. 5.2 ORR ORR is an essential electrochemical process for rechargeable metal-air batteries and fuel cells. MCSNs are proven to be ideal ORR electrocatalysts [114–116]. For example, compared to commercial Pt/C, Pd@PdFe CSNs with 3-atomic-thick, tensile-strained PdFe shells demonstrated 2.8-fold and 6.9-fold enhancements in mass and specific activities, respectively [117]. This enhanced ORR performance originated from synergistic tensile strain and alloy effects, which optimized intermediate binding. Ni@Pt CSNs demonstrated 1.95 mA cm−2 for specific activity and 490 mA mgPt −1 for mass activity at 0.9 V vs. RHE by modulating the d-band center of the thin Pt shell through electronic and strain effects [118]. The octahedral Pt3Ni@Pt CSNs with a ∼ 2 atomic layer Pt shell obtained through a co-etching process, which demonstrated an ∼ 8-fold ORR mass activity enhancement compared to benchmark Pt/C after 20,000 potential cycles [119]. The anisotropic mesoporous Pt@Pt-skin Pt3Ni core–shell frameworks showed outstanding mass activity of 6.69 A mgPt −1 and specific activity of 8.42 mA cm−2, as well as remarkable stability of 50,000 cycles (Fig. 10 ) [120]. Such Pt@Pt-skin Pt3Ni catalysts can merge the benefits of three-dimensional open mesopores for molecular access and compressive Pt-skin surface strains. Designing MCSNs with both high-Pt-utilization efficiency and enhanced catalytic performance remains a significant challenge. By regulating the Pd/Pt atomic ratio in Pd@Fe@Pt NPs with surface Pt decoration increased up to 70 % mass activity for ORR compared to commercial Pt/C [121]. This enhancement can be attributed to lowering the adsorption energy of oxygen-containing intermediates on Pt active sites through the lattice mismatch-induced strain and ligand effects. Furthermore, Co@PdPt CSNs on carbon nanotubes with surface Pt trimer decoration and a low Pt loading of 2.4 wt% exhibited a 30.6-fold increase in alkaline ORR activity compared to commercial Pt catalysts, along with excellent stability for over 322,000 cycles, owing to their unique surface charge localization induced by Pt3 decoration [37]. Additionally, Au@Co@PtCoAu CSNs exhibited significantly enhanced ORR performance, achieving specific and mass activities of 1.73 mA cm−2 and 0.692 A mgPt −1, respectively, which are 7-fold and 4-fold higher than those of the commercial Pt/C catalysts [122]. Remarkably, after 10,000 durability cycles, Au@Co@PtCoAu CSNs retained 93.86 % of their initial mass activity, demonstrating exceptional stability in contrast to the > 35 % loss observed for Pt/C under identical conditions. The compressive strain induced by Co interlayers optimized OH binding at Pt active sites, and thus boosted the electrochemical kinetics. 5.3 CO2RR Electrochemical reduction of CO2 to valuable chemicals offers a promising route to construct a sustainable future. MCSNs have emerged as a potential solution for addressing the complex CO2 conversion process, based on their tailorable lattice vacancies, strains, and electronic structures (Fig. 11 a) [16]. Noble metals, particularly Au and Pd, exhibit high activation energy for converting CO2 to *COOH intermediate, but low energy barriers for CO adsorption/desorption. Notably, PdAu@Pd with rich grain boundaries demonstrated a high faradaic efficiency (FE) of 94.3 % at −0.6 V vs. RHE and a fast reaction rate for CO2-CO conversion, owing to the formation of a linearly bonded CO intermediate that facilitated desorption [123]. AuPd@Pd exhibited ultrahigh activity (99.8 A gPd+Au −1) at an overpotential of 390 mV and maximum FE of 96.7 % (−0.6 V vs. RHE), due to the balanced *COOH/*CO adsorption energies resulting from strain and ligand effects between Au and Pd [124]. In addition, Ag@Cu CSNs with improved hierarchical interfaces demonstrated outstanding electrocatalytic CO2RR performance, achieving a maximum FE of 80.2 % for C2+ products and a current density of ∼320 mA cm−2 at −1.0 V (vs. RHE), as well as a notable stability over 60 h [125]. Mechanistic studies indicated that CO intermediates initially accumulated on the core, then migrated to the Cu surface, where they underwent energetically favorable C–C coupling to form ethanol. Moreover, Cu@Ag CSNs with an optimal Ag shell thickness showed high FEs for total C2 products (67.6 %) and ethylene (32.2 %) at −1.1 V (vs. RHE) along with enhanced electrocatalytic stability over 14 h [126]. This outstanding catalytic performance originated from the synergistic effect between Ag shell and Cu core, which strengthened CO adsorption at the Cu/Ag interfaces, accelerated charge transfer kinetics, and increased the electrochemically active surface area. Theoretical prediction suggested that octahedral Au@Cu CSNs might possess lower overpotentials for CO2-to-CH4 conversion compared to their icosahedral and cuboctahedral counterparts [127]. The electrochemical conversion of CO2 to liquid C1 and C2 chemicals has attracted much interest, due to their potential as efficient fuels or energy carriers. Recent studies demonstrated that Au@Cu CSNs with 7–8 layers of Cu atoms in their shells promoted the formation of H2, ethylene, and formic acid [128]. The trends in reactivity and selectivity were highly dependent on the catalyst composition, surface structure and strain effect. Furthermore, Cu@AuCu CSNs showed a composition-dependent volcano performance for CO2-to-CO electrochemical conversion (Fig. 11b, c), achieving an optimal FECO value of 94 % and a mass activity of 439 mA mgAu −1 at a 17 % Au content and −0.8 V (vs. RHE) [129]. DFT calculations suggested that Cu localized the d-bands of surface Au atoms, thereby reducing the formation energy of *COOH. Conversely, Au lowered the desorption energy of *CO, regenerating active sites for CO2RR. Cu@Pb core–shell nanocrystals with an ultrathin 0.7 nm-thick shell demonstrated a high current density of 196.8 mA cm−2 for C2+ liquid products from electrochemical CO2 reduction, surpassing most Cu-based catalysts [130]. DFT calculations indicated that the synergistic effect at the Cu-Pb interface lowered the formation energies of critical intermediates, *COOH (for CO2 reduction to CO) and *OCCOH (for C2+ product formation), boosting selectivity toward C2+ liquid products. Au@Pd core–shell aerogels exhibited remarkable CO selectivity at low overpotential (∼98 % FE at −0.5 V vs. RHE for 12 h) for electrochemical CO2 reduction, attributed to the synergistic effects between reduced CO desorption and high HER activation energy [131]. The immobilization of Ni@Ir CSNs on Si nanowires boosted photoelectrocatalytic CO2-to-formate conversion, achieving a yield rate of 58 μmol h−1 cm−2 and FE of 87 % under simulated light irradiation [132]. Precise pore diameter control (4.9 nm) in core–shell Ag@Cu catalysts induced optimal confinement of CO intermediates during CO2 electroreduction, achieving a 73.7 % FE for multicarbon (C2+) products at 300 mA cm−2 [133]. Finite-element simulations and in situ infrared spectroscopy confirmed that nanoscale pore geometry maximized local CO concentration and surface coverage of linearly adsorbed CO, while confinement effects promoted C–C coupling. Ultrathin Pb shells (0.7 nm) on Cu cores in Cu/Pb nanocrystals achieved exceptional CO2-to-C2+ conversion, delivering 81.6 % total C2+ FE and 49.5 % C2+ liquid selectivity at 196.8 mA cm−2 in flow cells, surpassing most Cu-based catalysts [130]. DFT indicated that the Cu/Pb interaction decreased the formation energies of important intermediates (*COOH for CO and *OCCOH for C2+), and then boosted the selectivity for liquid products. 5.4 N2/NO3 − reduction reaction (N2RR/NO3RR) The direct or mediated N2RR under ambient conditions offers an attractive pathway for sustainable ammonia production. However, its practical application is hindered by the lack of efficient electrocatalysts, primarily due to the highly stable N≡N bond and the inevitable HER competition [134,135]. The tunable elements and surface electronic structures of MCSNs enable charge transfer and protonation, making them ideal candidates for N2RR. For example, rationally designed CuAu@Cu CSNs featuring an ultrathin Cu skin (∼2 atomic layers) demonstrated remarkable catalytic activities for N2RR, delivering a superior NH3 production rate of 33.9 μg h−1 mgcat −1 with an FE of 24.1 % at a low potential of −0.2 V vs RHE in 0.1 M HCl electrolyte [136]. DFT calculations revealed that the unique bimetallic architecture synergistically combined a favourable tensile strain and ligand effect from ultrathin Cu skins, enhanced N2 affinity, and suppressed the HER process. In addition, Au3Cu@Cu nanocages exhibited an NH3 yield rate of 33.97 μg h−1 mgcat −1 and a FE of 21.41 % at −0.2 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 M Na2SO4 [137]. The enhanced N2RR activity of Au3Cu@Cu was attributed to three synergistic factors: (i) hollow cavities enabling reactant enrichment, (ii) porous core–shell heterostructured walls facilitating charge/mass transfer, and (iii) the bimetallic Au3Cu@Cu composition optimizing intermediate adsorption, collectively favoring N2RR over the competing HER. The electrocatalytic NO3-to-NH3 conversion emerges as a transformative approach for green ammonia synthesis and eco-remediative wastewater treatment. Although N2RR theoretically provides an ideal nitrogen feedstock, its industrial application still constrained by three fundamental limitations: (a) thermodynamic and kinetic challenges posed by the exceptionally stable N≡N triple bond (941 kJ mol−1), (b) restricted mass transfer due to poor N2 solubility in aqueous media, and (c) overwhelming competition from the HER. The NO3RR pathway demonstrates practical superiority through a synergistic triad of merits: (a) significantly reduced activation barriers due to the weaker N–O bonds (204 kJ mol−1), (b) enhanced reaction kinetics resulting from the superior aqueous solubility of nitrate, and (c) dual-functional capability that simultaneously converts ubiquitous water contaminants into value-added NH3 [138,139]. For example, the structurally ordered Cu@CuAu CSNs featuring single-atom alloy shells demonstrated unprecedented performance in electrochemical NO3-to-NH3 conversion, achieving an exceptional FE of 85.5 % at −0.5 V (vs. RHE) and an impressive NH3 yield rate of 8.47mol h−1 g−1 at −0.6 V (vs. RHE), with maintained stability over 20 operational cycles [40]. Such superior catalytic performances stemmed from a ligand-strain dual effect mechanism, wherein (001)-faceted Cu surface atoms improved NO3 − adsorption through d-band center modulation, while subsurface Au atoms induced electronic repulsion effects to decrease N-intermediate binding strengths. Similarly, Cu@CuAu CSNs with tailored compressive surface strain architecture demonstrated outstanding NO3RR performance, achieving a high NH3 production rate of 11.3 mol h−1 g−1 (at −0.6 V vs. RHE) with a high FE of 89.9 % (at −0.5 V vs. RHE) [140]. 5.5 Small organic molecule electrooxidation Several small organic molecules (SOMs), such as methanol, ethanol, formic acid and formaldehyde, have been investigated as efficient hydrogen source candidates for low-temperature fuel cells, due to their easy refueling and high theoretical power density [141,142]. The power density and stability of these fuel cells are highly dependent on the electrooxidation behaviour of SOMs on electrocatalysts. Meanwhile, electrooxidation of biomass-derived SOMs offers a promising approach for producing high-value-added chemicals from renewable energy sources [143]. Progresses are being continuously made by using MCSN catalysts in these areas. By modulating strain effects, electronic structures, or the CO-free dominated pathways, Pt-based MCSNs can serve as excellent electrocatalysts for the methanol oxidation reaction (MOR), a key half-reaction in direct methanol fuel cells. Au@PtIr CSNs showed the high mass activity of 784.72 mA mgPt −1 for MOR, owing to their rich active sites and outstanding anti-toxicity [144]. PtFe@PtRuFe CSNs with an ordered PtFe intermetallic core and a 3–5 atomic layer PtRuFe shell showed the enhanced anti-CO poisoning performance, Fe leaching resistance, and specific activity (∼1.57 times) for MOR compared to state-of-the-art PtRu/C catalysts (Fig. 12 ) [145]. The enhanced activity and CO tolerance of the PtFe@PtRuFe catalyst arose from three interconnected factors: its well-defined core–shell architecture, optimized elemental composition, and interfacial charge transfer from FeRu to Pt, which reduced the Pt-CO adsorption energy. Octahedral CuNi@PtCu CSNs with (111)-profiled PtCu facet exhibited superior MOR activity with a peak current density of ∼7.5 mA cm−2, outperforming commercial Pt/C and polyhedral CuNi@PtCu counterparts [53]. The enhanced MOR activity was primarily attributed to the lattice strain and octahedral shape effect. In addition, Pd-based MCSNs are promising MOR catalysts due to their low cost and high CO-resistance. For example, Au@Pd core–shell mesoporous nanoflowers showed excellent MOR activity and stability in alkaline electrolytes, because Au cores improved the antioxidation of Pd shell and reduced the adsorption energy of intermediates of Pd [146]. Au@PdRu CSNs delivered superior mass and specific activities of 1.56 A mgPd −1 and 3.51 mA cm−2 for MOR, respectively [147]. Pd@RhPd core–shell nanodendrites exhibited Rh content-dependent catalytic activity, with Pd@Rh0.07Pd showed an optimal combination of oxidation potential and current due to the synergistic Pd/Rh double active sites [148]. PtCuPd@Ru yolk-cage nanostructures showed superior electrocatalytic activity and stability toward MOR compared to PtCu nanoplates and commercial Pt/C catalysts [149]. PdAgSn@PtBi CSNs with a Pd-rich-core, Pt-rich-shell, and face-centered cubic structure showed outstanding specific and mass MOR activities of 4.7 mA cm−2 and 2874 mA mg(Pd+Pt) −1, respectively [150], owing to the highly exposed active sites and unique high-entropy coordination environment. A colloidal seed-mediated method achieved precise fabrication of octahedral CuNi@Pt-Cu core@shell nanocrystals with sub-nanometer Pt-shells (<1 nm) through controlled deposition/diffusion kinetics via capping ligands, temperature, and heating rate modulation [151]. These carbon-supported nano-octahedra exhibited superior MOR activity compared to commercial Pt/C and polyhedral counterparts, demonstrating how engineered core morphology and ultrathin Pt-shells synergistically enhance catalytic performance. Ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR) is of importance to the direct ethanol fuel cells, which are ideal candidates for portable electronic devices owing to their easy availability, high energy density, and non-toxicity [152]. The EOR typically involves a two-step reaction, involving the initial oxidation of ethanol to acetaldehyde or acetic acid, followed by further oxidation to CO2 [153]. Pt-containing CSN catalysts have been proven to be effective and efficient in improving EOR activity and selectivity. For example, the ternary Au@PtIr CSNs showed outstanding EOR performance of a low onset potential of 0.3 V (vs. RHE) and a peak current of 8.3 A mgall-metal −1, due to the synergy of complementary effects, including Au-induced tensile strain on PtIr and Ir-promoted dehydrogenation at low potentials [154]. Pd-containing CSNs are also viable alternatives due to their relatively low cost and considerable CO tolerance. The ternary Au@PdNi CSN catalyst demonstrated remarkable mass activity of 5891 mA mgPd −1 and stability for EOR, owing to enhanced electronic effects between Pd and AuNi [155]. In a mixed KOH/ethanol electrolyte, Ag@AgPd CSNs obtained a high mass activity of 12.7 A mgPd −1 and a significant 4.5-fold increase in CO2 selectivity compared to commercial Pt/C due to the induced interfacial tensile strain [156]. Au@Pd core–shell nanorods with a unique face-centered/cubic-hexagonal close-packed/face-centered cubic (fcc-2H-fcc) heterostructure demonstrated superior EOR performance with a mass activity of 6.82 A mgPd −1. This performance surpassed that of 2H-Pd NPs, fcc-Pd NPs and commercial Pd/C by factors of 2.44, 6.96, and 6.43, respectively (Fig. 13 ) [157]. The improved performance of Au@Pd nanorods can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the unusual 2H phase, the 2H/fcc phase boundary and the expansion of the Pd shell lattice. Formic acid electrooxidation reaction (FAOR) is a crucial half-reaction in direct formic acid fuel cells, and the design of efficient FAOR catalysts is essential for improving the power density and stability of these cells. Recent studies have focused on developing advanced catalysts, such as Ru@Pt CSNs with ordered and amorphous Ru cores and varying thicknesses [158]. The Ru@Pt0.75 exhibited a high specific activity of 1.95 mA cm−2 (∼25 times of Pt/C) owing to the reduced d-band center and weak CO adsorption resulting from the enhanced lattice strain of the Pt shell. Additionally, the concave CuPd@Pd tetrahedra exhibited outstanding FAOR mass activity of 501.8 A gPd −1 and specific activity of 49.3 A m−2, as well as superior CO-resistance and stability under harsh electrochemical conditions [159]. Trimetallic Ru@AuPt CSNs indicated that the Au/Pt atomic ratio and shell thickness can induce rich micro-strains, which further endowed a linear dependence of FAOR activity [160]. The optimal Ru@AuPt catalyst delivered a high specific activity of 4.14 mA cm−2, surpassing Pt/C by 52 times. Furthermore, investigations of Au@PdPt CSNs indicated that the structure of the alloyed PdPt shell was controlled by the lattice strain induced by the Au core, with optimal catalytic activity achieved at an intermediate degree of lattice strain [161]. High-entropy PtBiPb@PtBiNiCo CSNs demonstrated not only high specific activity of 27.2 mA cm−2 and mass activity of 7.1 A mgPt −1 for FAOR, but also achieved a large peak power density of 321.2 mW cm−2 with long-term stability [162]. The synergistic effect between the hexagonal intermetallic core/atomic layer shell structure and multi-element composition was responsible for the outstanding FAOR performance under operating fuel cell conditions. The electrooxidation of biomass-derived 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) offers a sustainable route to value-added chemicals, while reducing the overpotential of water splitting by replacing the OER [162–165]. 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), a product of 5-HMF electrooxidation, can be used to replace the petroleum-derived terephthalic acid to synthesize chemicals, polymers, and biofuels. A hierarchically layered CoFe@NiFe catalyst demonstrated significantly enhanced electrocatalytic performance for 5-HMF electrooxidation coupled with cathodic HER, achieving nearly 100 % 5-HMF conversion and 100 % FDCA FE at 1.40 V (vs. RHE) [166]. Co@Au CSNs grafted with Au branches demonstrated high electrocatalytic activity for 5-HMF electrooxidation, achieving a turnover frequency (TOF) of 1.73 s−1 at 1.55 V (vs. RHE) [167]. 6 Outlooks and future perspectives The investigation of low-cost MCSNs with superior catalytic performances has emerged as a rewarding new research field in electrochemistry. The recent surge in their development has been propelled by breakthroughs in advanced analytical techniques, particularly in TEM and XAS. In this review, we summarized the recent progress of MCSNs on account of their precise synthesis, unique features, advanced characterization techniques, and their use in innovative electrocatalytic applications. Despite the progress, the field remains in its early stages and faces significant challenges. One stumbling block is the lack of high-yield synthesis methods, because many MCSNs often lose their intrinsic physical and chemical properties during scale-up. Industrial applications often require both stability and scalability, necessitating the production of catalysts to be at least at a kilogram scale. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop innovative synthetic approaches for the large-scale production of MCSNs while preserving their structural and functional integrity. The shell thickness, particle size, and surface structure of MCSNs play crucial roles in determining the number of exposed interfacial active sites and the degree of strain, ligand or geometric effects. However, achieving precise control over these parameters remains a challenge. One potential approach to address this challenge is the development of modified chemical vapor deposition techniques. Furthermore, there is a continued need to either downsize MCSNs to under 2 nm in diameter or explore the incorporation of more than three elements into either the core or shell. This is particularly relevant as metal clusters and high-entropy alloys have demonstrated excellent catalytic properties in recent studies. While regulating preparation parameters can obtain strong synergistic effects between the core and shell, thereby enhancing the electrocatalytic activities of MCSNs, deep insights into their dynamic catalytic reactions through in situ, operando, or other innovative characterization techniques are necessary. For instance, it is essential to investigate whether the reconstruction of MCSNs under electrochemical conditions creates new active sites and how interface strains influence reactant adsorption and product desorption. Moreover, a way to evaluate different electrochemical reactions from a unified viewpoint is needed. For example, reactions like HER and OER often compete in CO2RR, N2RR/NO3RR and small organic molecule electro-oxidations. A comprehensive understanding of these reactions will facilitate the tailored design of MCSNs for specific applications. Computational simulations can provide valuable insights into complex catalytic processes and predict efficient MCSNs configurations, thereby guiding experimental efforts. Future research should focus on developing novel MCSNs using earth-abundant elements through computationally guided, scalable designs to meet the industrial demands: (a) cost-effectiveness optimization via earth-abundant core materials with ultrathin noble metal shells, minimizing precious metal consumption while leveraging strain or ligand effects for enhanced catalysis; (b) degradation-resistant architectures (e.g., high-entropy alloy shells or dynamic self-repairing interlayers) to mitigate corrosion under industrial operating conditions, (c) scalable green synthesis, including one-pot ligand-free methods guided by computation, and microfluidic reactors or continuous-flow systems enabling gram-to-kilogram scale production with atomic-level precision, (d) device-ready integration through reactor-compatible 3D electrodes and standardized manufacturing protocols for seamless industrial compatibility, (e) AI-driven design and screening employing multimodal-trained deep neutral networks to predict optimal core–shell configurations from datasets combining DFT-calculated adsorption energies and experimental stability-activity landscapes, alongside autonomous robotic workflows for synthesis and high-throughput validation, (f) operando structural interrogation using advanced techniques (e.g., cryo-electron tomography, or in situ electrochemical LCTEM) to track atomic-scale structural evolution during reactions. By combining these strategies with advanced characterization techniques, a deeper understanding of the formation process, structural strain, and reconstruction of MCSNs, as well as their catalytic mechanisms under electrochemical conditions, is in fact possible. We hope that the present review will promote the development of MCSNs in electrocatalytic applications, and even realize far more potential beyond electrochemical science, ultimately leading to a sustainable future. XiangyunXiao received the Ph.D. degree in chemical engineering at Kyung Hee University in 2021, and then worked as a postdoctoral researcher at the same university until 2022. She is now working in Prof. Xinchun Yang’s group at Shenzhen Institutes of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, as a postdoctoral research fellow. Her research focuses on the controllable synthesis of nanocatalysts for hydrogen and ammonia energy. DoufengWang is now a Ph.D. candidate in University of Chinese Academy of Sciences under the supervision of Prof. Hui-Ming Cheng and Prof. Xinchun Yang. He works in the field of the controllable synthesis of functional nanomaterials and their applications in HER and NO3RR. CaferT.Yavuz received his PhD from Rice University in 2008 with a Welch scholarship and was a postdoctoral researcher at University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB) (2008–2010). He was a faculty member at Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) from 2010 to 2020. Currently, he is a professor of chemistry at King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST) with a research focus on nano and porous materials design and synthesis for applications in the environment, particularly for CO2 capture and conversion. XinchunYang received his PhD from Kobe University in 2018 and was a postdoctoral researcher at National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), KAIST and Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology (UNIST) from 2018–2021. Currently, he is an associate professor at Shenzhen Institutes of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His research focuses on the development of advanced metal cluster catalysts for heterogeneous catalysis and hydrogen energy conversion. Hui-Ming Cheng has been the director of both the Advanced Carbon Research Division of Shenyang National Laboratory for Materials Science, Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, since 2001, and the Institute of Technology for Carbon Neutrality, Shenzhen Institutes of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, since 2021. He is a member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and a fellow of The World Academy of Sciences (TWAS). His research activities mainly focus on energy materials and devices, carbon nanotubes, graphene, and other 2D materials. He published over 800 papers with an h-index of 158, and is a Highly Cited Researcher in three fields of materials science, chemistry, and environment and ecology. He has given over 230 plenary/keynote/invited lectures at various conferences and won a few domestic and international awards. He is the founding Editor-in-Chief of Energy Storage Materials and has spun off several high-tech companies.

coredata.dc:description: Metallic core–shell nanoparticles (MCSNs) have attracted significant research interest in electrochemical energy conversion owing to their distinctive microstructures and superior catalytic performances. By rationally designing a metallic core with a specific surface (shell), synergistic interactions between the core and the shell, benefiting from the intrinsic strain, ligand, geometric, and ensemble effects, can endow multi-metallic CSNs with highly enhanced activity, selectivity, and stability in electrocatalytic reactions, compared to their monometallic counterparts. In this review, we outline the key breakthroughs—especially in the past 5 years—of MCSNs, focusing on their precise design/synthesis, intrinsic effects arising from core–shell interactions, state-of-the-art characterization techniques, and exceptional performance in critical electrochemical reactions, including water splitting, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), N2/NO3 − reduction reaction (N2RR/NO3RR), and small organic molecule electrooxidations. We further discuss the ongoing challenges and opportunities for MCSNs, particularly in achieving computationally guided design/atomic-precision synthesis, enabling scalable production, and advancing in situ or operando characterization methods. We hope that the present review will inspire chemists working in this field to develop new MCSNs for sustainable energy applications.
